title: About
text:
Hi! My name is Vladimir Kukushkin, and I have over 10 years of experience as a data scientist / data analyst. The slash signifies that I typically work at the intersection of product analytics and data science, tackling problems that require advanced techniques like predictive analytics, causal inference, and building statistical models. My specialization is user behavior analysis a.k.a. quantitative UX research or, more broadly, sequential data analysis.
My projects:

retentioneering. An open-source Python library for user behavior analysis.

My publications:

Prediction of Hourly Earnings and Completion Time on a Crowdsourcing Platform (KDD-2020)
On the Relation Between Assessor’s Agreement and Accuracy in Gamified Relevance Assessment (SIGIR-2015)

title: Welcome to Journal Papers Product Minds Club
text:
My name is Vladimir Kukushkin. I’ve been working more than 10 years as a data analyst / data scientist. The slash sign means here that I usually deal with product analytics problems requiring data science techniques, like predictive analytics, causal inference, building statistical models, etc. In particular, I specialize in user behavior analysis a.k.a. quantitative UX research or, more general, in any sequential data analysis. Besides working on these problems as a data analyst, I played major roles in developing retentioneering open-source Python library aimig to facilitate this type of researches.
In my humble opinion, undeservably little attention is payed to this area. Even though such researches are quite sophisticated compared to traditional funnel or cohort analysis, a deep dive into Quant UX sheds the light onto real understanding how your product’s users behave. In particular:

What drives them to churn/purchase/subscription/etc. (causal inference),
What clusters the users form (cluster analysis),
What caused some unexpected behavior that was captured by our dashboard charts (root cause analysis).

And since there’s not much literature devoted to this topic, I’m going to carefully collect and review any papers, books, and publications that would seem interesting to me.
Just like Sgt. Pepper’s Lonely Hearts Club Band has expanded the horizons of perceptions, I will be glad if this journal club attracts the attention of dat aanalysts and data scientists and helps expand their horizons too. And yes, “club” in the title means that I hope to find here some enthusiasts and discuss with them any aspects of these topics.  ♫ Music playing We’re Sgt. Pepper’s Lonely Hearts Club Band We hope you will enjoy the show

title: Welcome to Journal Papers Product Minds Club
text:
I’ve been working as a data scientist / data analyst over 10 years. The slash signifies that I typically work at the intersection of product analytics and data science, tackling problems that require advanced techniques like predictive analytics, causal inference, and building statistical models. My specialization is in user behavior analysis a.k.a. quantitative UX research or, more broadly, in analyzing sequential data. In addition to working as a data analyst, I played a key role in developing an open-source Python library retentioneering, which aims to simplify research in this area.
In my view, this field deserves much more attention than it currently receives. While these analyses are more complex than traditional funnel or cohort analysis, quantitative UX provides a deeper understanding of how users interact with your product. It reveals insights such as:

What drives users to churn, make purchases, subscribe, etc. (causal inference),
What segments users form (cluster analysis),
What caused unexpected behavior in dashboard charts (root cause analysis)
What distinguishes one user group from another, e.g. mobile VS desktop, AB-experiment groups, before and after release.

These research questions are not an empty sound. Finding the answers helps identify product bottlenecks, understand what drives user satisfaction or dissatisfaction, and ultimately improve your product. This is the core purpose of product analytics.
Given the lack of substantial literature on the subject, here I aim to collect and review papers, books, and publications that I find insightful.
Like how Sgt. Pepper’s Lonely Hearts Club Band expanded horizons in music, I hope this journal club will attract data analysts and data scientists eager to broaden their understanding of these topics. The term “club” in the title reflects my wish to engage with enthusiasts and foster discussions around these fascinating subjects.  ♫ Music playing ♫ We’re Sgt. Pepper’s Lonely Hearts Club Band We hope you will enjoy the show
